ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The pace was a little too fast but it allowed us to cover a lot of material, and studying for the quiz each week helped solidify the material a little better.

This class was challenging and engaging, and although it demanded a lot, it never felt like tedious work. Dr. Anisfeld's readings, quizzes, and lectures were well organized and interesting, and he was very attentive to answering students' questions and generally fostering discussions about unclear topics. I really enjoyed this class-definitely my favorite of the semester.

The workload was fair given that the class was 4 units. Shimi is a wonderful instructor and very thoughtful about what readings he assigns. The majority of the time the reading assignments were well-picked---for both quantity and quality. Loved having the field trips, but a few of them could be improved by more hands-on activities, worksheets, or problem solving. (The phytoplankton lab was an exception to this).

Shimi was very receptive to student feedback, made himself extremely available to students outside of class, and was very knowledgeable about the material. It was a lot of work, but I got out what I put it. He is a very dedicated and effective instructor!

Q3 course load was a bit heavier, but it was a 4 credit course so that is understandable/needed Q12 coastal ecosystems is not in my core curriculum so it wouldn't be 100% useful for people in my field however I would recommend this course without hesitation to people with a variety of interests. This was without a doubt one of the best courses I have ever taken. Shimi is an impeccable instructor that can explain difficult concepts in an accessible way. He expects a lot but also puts so much effort in himself that putting in the work feels more like holding up your end up in a team effort than a chore. If you'd press me to find something in the class to improve I'd say students could do more presentation type application of their knowledge for example applying what we learned ourselves on other ecosystems (worldwide?) but that would simply be an extension of the last assignment. I'd give this course without a doubt a 100/100.

I loved this course! The 5 hour meeting times were daunting; but I got so much out of the lectures, guest speakers, and field trips. I feel really well-grounded in the current literature, and have been taught by Shimi how to read scientific publications with skepticism and ask questions. Would recommend 100%.

Question 10: I thought SA did an absolutely incredible job teaching this course. His commitment to each and every student was amazing. I have never had a professor as attentive to student questions or who took more time in an out of class to explain concepts both directly pertaining to the course or outside of the course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Shimi puts a number of coastal ecosystem and science issues into context, effectively communicating the nuance and uncertainty in the science. You'll walk away from the course informed on the obstacles that scientists face, ecosystems face, and we as a whole face due to degrading coastal ecosystems. You will learn a lot I also enjoyed the class discussions of the readings and in class materials.
Small class format, lots of discussion and participation by students, great to be able to have a dialogue during lectures

Breaking up class time with speakers, field trips, and presentations was helpful. I liked that the field trips did not have a requirement to fill out a worksheet or write a paragraph about the trip. This allowed me to relax and learn through observation without focusing on completing a worksheet.

I really enjoyed the discussions that we had about primary literature, especially comparing articles that produced contradicting conclusions. I think a tendency that many students develop (myself included) is to read peer-reviewed studies and take them at face-value, but this course showed me how to critically analyze scientific research and more closely evaluate methods, data analysis, and overall study design.
The quality and organization of the instruction. The size of the class, the subject of the course.

Shimi's instruction was really excellent. He made all of the material as clear as it possibly could be in order for us to have the most fully engaged conversation. I have never enjoyed class discussion as much as I did in this class -- everyone participated in equal amounts and I felt like I learned so much from this aspect of the course.
Field trips, readings, instructions
Shimi is by far the most prepared lecturer I have had at FES; the detail with which he explains material is excellent and he knows how to ensure that people are absorbing concepts.
The field trips were super interesting and helpful.

I though this was an amazing course. The material was incredibly in-depth but broad in scope. While much of the course focuses on salt marshes, I thought that this was an advantage as it allowed as in-depth examination that carried over in many ways to the other ecosystems examined. SA was one of the best professors that I've taken a course with. Amazed that he took the time to answer and integrate each and every students reading questions into lecture each week.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Some of the readings I found to be a bit burdensome. Particularly the chapter readings on a given topic. Most of the scientific papers chosen were worthwhile reads, but the chapters were often not. I'm not sure how to strike the right balance between coming into class with a base knowledge of a given topic versus how much of it can be effectively covered in class. Maybe instead of devoting each class period to a given topic, the basic critical information on a given topic can be covered at the end of one class period, allowing students to then synthesize more nuanced/complex papers on the topic before the following class, and then these papers can be discussed in that following class.
It was hard to get a lot out of the problem sets when we did them at the end of class when my brain was turning into mush.

Sometimes I would have preferred if we reviewed the last week's quiz after taking the current week's quiz. For me it was hard to switch gears so quickly between quiz review, quiz-taking and catching up on old lecture material, then starting new lecture material.
The task for the paper/presentation assignment might be refined in order to make more use of this time.

I did not find the problem sets particularly useful (too in-the-weeds for my purposes) and I think 2-3 field trips would have sufficed in terms of learning opportunities, although everyone enjoyed the field trips and opportunities to get out into the field are fairly hard to come by at FES.

It is hard for me to say anything that needs improvement with this course. One thing that I would say is that I would have appreciated a bit more stability in the reading load week to week. Some weeks the reading would be really light, while other weeks completely overwhelming. On the same note, I was a bit confused by what "skim" meant for some readings, as often these readings that would be the main focus of discussion.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Great! The field trips fit in so well with the lecture -- it might be nice to go on a field trip that is to a system other than salt marsh, or to go somewhere with an interactive component - run an experiment, collect some specimens or something like that.
Very effective.

I think the relationship was really well thought out. Our readings paired nicely with field trips, and I felt prepared to ask questions about the professionals' jobs. Literally getting our feet wet helped us understand the systems were reading about and discussing in lecture.
Thought that transitions between lecture and discussion were seamless. Also loved how discussion was integrated into the lectures on most occasions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: There are not many hydrology related courses and this one went really deep into the subject without loosing people that had a superficial interest in it.

I am interested in coastal management and policy. There were times where the technical aspects of the course seemed unnecessary for someone with these goals, but anyone interested in water resources management or ocean and coastal issues should have a solid understanding of the physical and biological constraints that shape these systems, and so would benefit from this class.

I want to be a coastal manager. This class taught us how to read the science to understand how to manage, how to gauge management implications, and how to balance the needs of the people with ecosystem conservation.
I am interested in coastal management and with coastal ecology. This course was essential for both.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: In classes taught by Shimi, you'll leave with a better understanding of the topic and a greater interest. Coastal ecosystems is not my primary focus, but after taking this class I'll be more conversant in coastal issues and I also find myself more interested in them.
I have always had an interest in coastal ecosystems and I wanted to learn more about them so I can better manage them.

It looked interesting, and it covered both science and management topics. I found it to be a very useful course to start thinking about marine and coastal science in the context of management and policy.
To be exposed to the wonderful world of coastal ecosystems, take a class with Shimi, and practice reading scientific papers.
Science!
See above question.
This course is essential to the work that I will be doing at an MESc student and it is one of the few courses offered at FES regarding marine and/or coastal ecosystems.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely yes
Yes, although we covered so much detail that sometimes it was hard to see the big picture of what I actually learned and how I can apply it to a job.
Yes, they did--very well.
Yes.
I learned more than in any other course that I've ever took.

Yes, for the most part. There are certainly times when some of us may have appreciated greater attention to the management implications of some more technical constructs, but Shimi does clearly try to incorporate these considerations while also making sure he is presenting the entire biophysical story - so given timing constraints he probably walks this line as best as he can.
Yes.
My learning in this course far exceeded by expectations. I thought that the material was in-depth yet broad.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Some knowledge of coastal ecosystems is helpful as well as a strong background in physical sciences.

Ask lots of questions during class! This was the best part for sure--Dr. Anisfeld is incredibly good at explaining tricky concepts, and he's always enthusiastic about discussing other topics that students feel might relate to the course material.

Great overview of ecosystem science. Don't shy away from this course if you don't have a strong science background, it is very accessible. Also if you want to improve your ability to read scientific papers, this is the course for you!
Take it, but be prepared to put in the work. You'll be rewarded.
Take it. If it seems too technical at first, hang in there, because it's still important background information and ultimately it's up to you how much of that detail you want to take in.
Keep up with the readings. Shimi is an awesome professor (one of the best at FES), so use his knowledge and helpful attitude to your advantage!

Space the readings out between class periods as they often cannot be completed the day before. Take advantage of SA requirement to submit questions, he answers all of them every week! Focus readings in particular on the figures and review figures from readings before class.
